chapter.title: Overview of Globus Toolkit Documentation
chapter.para: This document includes the policies and guidelines behind the documentation for GT distributions, requirements for documents and help for using the DocBook XML Schema for common documentation elements.

Our goal is to provide comprehensive documentation in a clear concise manner and in language that is not too technical or obscure. To that end, we encourage all feedback, suggestions and comments for improving our documentation and finding ways to make the information more easily understandable. For broken links and other simple technical issues with using the docs online, send an email to webmaster@globus.org. For everything else, file a bug in Bugzilla (use the Documentation project).
We thank you ahead of time for your help.

chapter.title: Globus Toolkit Documentation Strategy
chapter.para: Starting with GT 4.0, we use templates of the minimum required topics for each project. During the development process, more and more information is added and refined with each release. This process is facilitated by the Documentation Coordinator and Technical Product Manager. With each development release, the documentation becomes more and more complete. This iterative process allows the documentation to be built up over time instead of in a rush right before final release. When development for the next major version begins, we copy the existing documentation to a docs/development/[version]-drafts/ directory and then the Project Chairs build on those docs.

section.title: Fragments
section.para: To reduce duplication and make sure we have a single source for all information, we also utilize 'fragments' of frequently used information. For example, a brief overview of the project is stored in [project_name]_Overview_Brief_Frag.xml and embedded wherever such a description is needed. Thus, any update to the Overview fragment is updated in each place it has been embedded and remains standard throughout the documentation. As you can guess from this example, such frags have the following naming convention: [project_name]_[description]_Frag.xml

warning.para: Fragments are most useful for small chunks of information that would be embedded within a section. If the content expands to include subsections to which you want to link (using ids), DocBook generates errors if it is embedded more than once, as that creates duplicate ids. In such situations, it is better to make the information a standalone page.

section.title: Standard organization
section.para: Our templates provide a standard organization for all system administrator, user and developer guides for all projects of the Globus Toolkit. If a section does not apply for a project, there will be a statement to the effect: "This section does not apply for this project." For example, if a project does not have a GUI interface, then the [project]_Interface_GUI_Frag.xml file should explicitly say so. The benefit is that the reader will know the project does not have a GUI interface instead of looking for GUI information and wondering if it was simply left out.

From time to time, there will be information that is not compatible with the standard organization. In these cases, you have the option of creating standalone pages covering the topic. These standalone pages are represented in the table of contents as an appendix item (see .

section.title: Release cycle for documentation
section.para: The following list outlines what happens with documentation in a typical GT release cycle:

listitem.para: Once development begins for the next major release (we'll use 4.2 as an example release), a new folder is added to the development docs directory: toolkit/docs/development/4.2-drafts/.
Documentation Coordinator updates files for the upcoming release (changes version numbers, etc.)
Developers start updating documents in this development directory for the upcoming release.
For each development release leading up to the stable release:
After source code freeze, a corresponding directory is added to the development docs directory - for example, ../toolkit/docs/development/4.1.5.
The drafts directory is frozen and copied over to the new directory.
Documentation Coordinator updates references to release numbers.
Documentation Coordinator and Technical Product Manager go over development documentation for any other necessary revisions.
Release notes are completed and the development release is announced.
Freeze is lifted for drafts directory.
Before final stable release:
A new directory is added to the docs directory - for example, .../toolkit/docs/4.2/.
After source code freeze, the drafts directory is frozen and copied over to the new directory.
Documentation Coordinator updates references to release numbers.
Documentation Coordinator and Technical Product Manager go over development documentation for any other necessary revisions.
Release notes are completed and the final release is announced.
After final stable release, the drafts directory is removed.
The final stable release documentation is used for all subsequent incremental releases as well.
Clarity in presentation.
Use best practices learned from the print world, web, and other media, about use of grammar, space, writing style, etc:

Consistency. It's important to be consistent in the use of terms and names for your project. For example, make sure that when you name a project, you consistently use the same name throughout documentation to avoid confusion.

Use standardized language. Consider international readers by not using slang or colloquial terms - many of your readers use English as a second language. This also helps make translation easier for anyone interested in translating the documentation for internationalization efforts.
All jargon used in documentation needs to be defined (using the glossary feature). Use standardized terms when available, avoiding implicit understanding of specific Globus Toolkit terms.

Single source - This practice significantly reduces obsolescence in writing and the burden of maintaining up-to-date documentation:
Show where to find information instead of duplicating information - use a cross-reference or create fragments using system entities - as long as there are no subsections with ids, you can embed them anywhere in the set of release manuals.
If the information is not found elsewhere, then create one place for it where others can refer to it (contact the Documentation Coordinator if you have any doubts about how to do so).

Consider Globus Toolkit documentation as a set of books (an encyclopedic set organized like an atlas) that contains volumes (books). Each book contains parts, chapters and sections, where each chapter is a web page. This designation helps create Globus Toolkit books in PDF, and helps new readers visualize how the documentation is organized.

section.title: Key Concepts
section.para: Key Concepts guides are at the 'family' level (common/, data/, execution/, info/, and security/) and explain important concepts about the technologies within that family.
There is a very basic outline for key concepts but they should be customized for the specific technology they're describing.
We encourage the use of graphics to demonstrate your key concepts!
As necessary, we also encourage adding standalone files if you have a large amount of information you want to break down into separate files.

The Key Concepts Guide has the following required topics:

listitem.para: Overview: Provides high-level overview of the features of the component, as well as a description of the problem space of relevance to the component. The discussion should be aimed at readers who are non-experts.
Conceptual Details: The bulk of this guide, includes several paragraphs outlining the fundamental concepts that underly the component.
Related Documents: Link to other documents (internal or external, whitepapers, presentations, etc.) that supplement the Overview.

Troubleshooting: Describes user-friendly help on common problems they may encounter.

Configuring: Embeds the [project]_Interface_Configuring_Frag.xml fragment for full information on configuration settings [cris: should we also embed environmental variables frag?].

section.title: Developer's Guides
section.para: Keep in mind the following when you edit Developer's Guides:

List practical development and diagnostics tools and methodologies.
List/link to Globus Toolkit development resources, API docs, schema files, etc.. Remember you can use ViewCVS to link to the latest versions of schema, WSDL, and other files.

section.para: The Developer's Guide has the following required topics:

listitem.para: Introduction: Introduces the project to developers (people who use the programmatic public interfaces of GT).

Before you begin: Collects information useful to developers before they start working with the technology. Embeds the following fragments: Features Summary, Tested Platforms, Backward Compatibility, Tech Dependencies and Security Consideration.
Architecture and design overview: Describes the architecture and design at a high-level with links to architecture and design docs. Diagrams are strongly encouraged.

Public interfaces: Describes the semantics and syntax of the APIs and WSDL for the component, along with descriptions of domain-specific structured interface data, by embedding the following fragments: API, Commandline (linked, not embedded), Config (linked, not embedded), Domain, Environment Variables, GUI, Protocol and WSDL.
Usage scenarios: Describes how to use the programmatic interfaces of the project and provides examples.

Tutorials: Links to any developer tutorials. Tutorials do not conform to a template, but they are strongly encouraged. The files can be in any format as long as they are available online. You can add the files to your project's doc CVS repository or on your own web space. Keep in mind the following when writing them:
Use cross references to Developers Guide instead of duplicating information.
List suggestions for installing and setting up a development environment; these can be annotated links to the top-level Installation Guide.
Provide working examples.
Include general rules to follow for stability, scalability.
Include a summary of important links used by developers.
Note any deprecated tools and methods by linking to prior versions instead of describing them in current docs.
If there are no tutorials, write "There are no tutorials available at this time."
Debugging: Provides information for debugging the project.
Troubleshooting: Describes help for common problems developers may experience.
Related Documentation: Links to PDFs and whitepapers about protocols, etc., about the project.

chapter.title: Why DocBook?
chapter.para: All Globus Toolkit documentation will be marked up to conform to the DocBook XML DTD. Theoretically, any strict DTD would have been sufficient. However, DocBook is a publishing standard based on XML with similar goals to the Globus Toolkit Documentation project. Some specific reasons why we are using DocBook:

listitem.para: It is open-source.
A growing community surrounds DocBook (has mailing lists).
A number of free and commercial tools are available for editing and publishing DocBook documents.
It enables us to publish in a variety of formats (HTML, PDF, etc.)
XML separates content from presentation: It relieves each contributor of the burden of presentation, freeing each writer to focus on content and sharing knowledge.
It is well tested technology. (It has been in development since the early 1990's).

chapter.para: The following DocBook primer walks you through the basics, and should cover the needs for 95 percent of the documentation we produce. Remember to:

listitem.para: Always close your tags with corresponding end-tags and to not use other tag minimization.
Write all elements and attributes in lowercase.
Quote all attributes.

chapter.title: Setting Up DocBook
chapter.para: There are many ways to work with the DocBook documentation. At its simplest, you need CVS access, then if you know how the code works, you can edit the XML files in a text editor. However, many people are more comfortable setting up a separate test environment, you'll need some things to duplicate the processing that occurs to the files when producing the HTML/PDF output.
The following can help you with the Globus Toolkit Docbook XML documentation:

listitem.para: Docbook XML DTD version 4.4 - The document type definition for XML. You can find an RPM or DEB package or you can download a zip file from the site linked from here.
XSL Stylesheets version 1.69.1 (docbook-xsl) - The stylesheets to convert to HTML. We have been using a stylesheet based upon NWalsh's "chunk.xsl".

xsltproc - The processor that will take an XML document and, given a xsl stylesheet, convert it to HTML. It needs libxml2 and libxslt (available in RPM and DEB formats or from xmlsoft.org). It comes with xmllint, which will be very useful for debugging.
Some editing tool. Some options are Oxygen XML Editor, Syntext Serna (WYSIWYG), and Emacs with the psgml mode. You can compare these and other editing tools here.

chapter.para: For more information about how to set up a test environment, see the dev.globus wiki.

chapter.title: Creating New Docs/Appendix
chapter.para: For the most part, you only need to edit existing DocBook files. However, the following information is helpful if you need to create a new standalone doc.

note.simpara: We only encourage standalone docs to supplement information that is already in the templates for standard documentation or for information that does not fit within the template's structure. If you're not sure, contact the Documentation Coordinator.

section.title: Writing New Docs/Appendix
section.para: First, you need to define a title for your document. Try to use a title that is as informative as possible using the fewest amount of words possible. Also, try to compose a title with certain 'keywords' that will catch the attention of readers who are looking for this information.

Then start thinking about the possible sections and subsections you will have in your document. Make sure you coordinate with the Documentation Coordinator to make sure you're not writing something that someone else has already written.

section.xreflabel: Adding New Docs/Appendix to Your Release Manuals
section.title: Adding New Docs/Appendix to Your Release Manuals
section.para: Make sure your XML is properly named - you should use the project name that prepends other files in your directory (for example Java_WS_Core) and then one or two words describing the contents. Note that as an appendix, your DocBook code will start with the <appendix> element. When hooking up with your documentation, however, the <appendix> element (with id and xreflabel and even title) will be in the [project]/index.xml file.

listitem.para: Make sure new file is added to CVS in your project's directory.

Add a system entity reference to the entities file. To do this, download the following from CVS ([path to doc version]/entities) and look for your project's list of entities. Then add yours in alpha order. For example, if GridFTP was adding an appendix on named GridFTP_Special_Topic.xml, this would be the new line to add: <!ENTITY GridFTP_Special_Topic SYSTEM "data/gridftp/GridFTP_Special_Topic.xml"> Commit change to CVS.

Add entity reference to your project's index.xml file (using the example in the previous step, that would be &GridFTP_Special_Topic;. You should follow how other chapters and appendixes are added in your index.xml file - but here's an example of what GridFTP would add (make sure it is added:
<appendix id="gridftp-special-topic" xreflabel="GridFTP Special Topic"><title>GridFTP Special Topic</title> &GridFTP_Special_Topic; </section> And commit this change to CVS.

section.para: Look at the existing files in your project (or checkout another project and look at their code) to see how the code is used in practice.

chapter.title: Structure of a DocBook Set
chapter.para: For each version, release manuals are essentially one long XML file with the root node <set>. Below that we use a two-tiered basic directory where a family of projects (for example data/) starts with the <book> element and below that each project starts with the <part> element. (and there may be further subdirectories as necessary for the project).

Focusing on the project-level, which is the only level most writers will need to worry about, each <part> is structured as follows (we'll use GridFTP as an example, which can be found in .../toolkit/docs/4.0/data/gridftp/):
chapter.screen:
set (the top element - includes all code for all docs within a version) | +--book (this element includes doc code for a family of projects, such as common/ or data/) | +--part (includes doc code for one project, such as common/javawscore/) | +--chapter (each chapter element is output as one HTML page) | ---------+------------------------------------------------------ | +--section (sections divide content underneath a chapter) | +--section | +--section (a nested section element becomes a subsection) | +--refentry (for commandline documentation)
+--appendix | +--section | +--section

note.simpara: Note that we use <section> tags recursively - simply nest section tags to make subsections.

chapter.para: The following is some DocBook code representing how the above info 'nests':
chapter.screen:
<part> <title>GridFTP Release Manuals</title> <chapter><title>GridFTP Developer's Guide</title>
<section><title>Introduction</title> <para>[content]</para> </section>
<section><title>Architecture and design</title> <section><title>Design Overview</title> <para>[content]</para> </section> </section>
</chapter> </part>
chapter.para: In the implementation, the code is broken up into several modular XML files (see the next chapter, ). Each chapter is output as a single web page (this also applies to <reference>, <appendix>, and <article> elements). Many of these pages embed fragments (which are separate XML files (as described in ).
Take a look at the files of existing DocBook documents, or see the following chapter to get an idea of how they are tied together.

For example, the system entity for:

The entities file contains such mappings for every xml file/fragment used in a version's DocBook code.

section.title: Text entities
section.para: Similar to system entities, text entities map a 'nickname' to a string of text. There are a few in particular that you should use in your documentation:

listitem.para: &docpath; - Maps to the url to this version's doc. Useful if you need to use a <ulink> within a version's doc but do not want to update with each version. For example, for 4.2-drafts/, &docpath; equals &docpath;.
&version; - Maps to the current 3-digit version number (for example, 4.1.0). Useful for referencing the current version in your docs without having to update for each version.
&shortversion; - Maps to the current 2-digit version number (for example, 4.2). Useful for referencing the current version in your docs without having to update for each version.
&previousversion; - Maps to the previous 2-digit version number (for example, 4.0). Useful for referencing the previous version without having to update for each version.

chapter.title: Paragraphs (<para> and <simpara>)
chapter.para: Not surprisingly, the paragraph tag, <para>, is the most used tag in our documentation. Not only can you use it to separate your text into separate paragraphs, it may also contain block level structures (lists, figures, and so on).

But there is another, similar tag that is also used - <simpara>. This tag also separates content into separate paragraphs, however, it is more restrictive in that it can only contains text characters.

important.para: You also need <para> or <simpara> tags around text in the following elements: <listitem>, <important> <note>, <tip>, and <warning>.
For example, if you are using an itemizedlist, you need to write the code as follows:

section.title: Brackets
section.para: Brackets (< and >) used within the flow of text (ie, within <para> or <simpara> elements) must be represented in code as follows: the opening bracket is represented as < (short for "less than") and the closing bracket is represented as > (short for "greater than".

chapter.title: Headings and Sections
chapter.para: Headings are determined by DocBook elements as follows:

listitem.para: Heading 1 - <set>, <book>, <part>
Heading 2 - <chapter>, <appendix>, <article>, <refentry>
Heading 3+ - <section> (Sections nest recursively to make subsections - each section will correspond to a heading level in the HTML/PDF output.)

chapter.para: Each of the abovementioned elements must also have two attributes (id and xreflabel) and be followed by a <title> tag.

section.title: id attribute
section.para: The first attribute, id, is standard and can be used with all elements. It comes in very handy when cross-referencing between documents (more about this when talking about ). The value of id must be unique throughout a version's documentation (throughout the <set>).
When it comes to creating unique ids for your <section>s, please use the following naming convention:
section.screen: [name of your project folder]-[short name for doc]-[short term related to this section]
section.para: For example, this would be a unique id for the "Introduction" section of the GridFTP System Administrator's Guide: gridftp-admin-intro

section.title: xreflabel attribute
section.para: The other attribute is xreflabel. The value of this attribute becomes the link title of any cross- references to the section.
For example, the xreflabel for this section is "xreflabel attribute" and a cross-reference to this section will look like this: .

section.title: <title> tag
section.para: The opening <section> tag is followed by the <title> tag. The value of the <title> tag is usually the same as the xreflabel attribute and becomes the text of the heading for the section in the HTML/PDF output.
For example, the value of the <title> tag for this section is "Headings and Sections", which is the heading above. The level of the heading (h1, h2, etc) depends on how deeply the section is nested.

section.title: Example
section.para: For example, the topic you are reading right now looks like this in the DocBook XML file:
section.screen:
<section id="heading" xreflabel="Headings and Sections"> <title>Headings and Sections</title>
...
</section>
section.para: Inside this section, you can further nest <section> tags, each with the same requirements: id and xreflabel attributes, and a <title> tag.

chapter.title: Documenting Code (<computeroutput> and <filename>)
chapter.para: For displaying a snippet of code, a filename or anything else you just want to appear as a part of a sentence, we normally use the <computeroutput> or <filename> elements. They take the place of the <code> or <tt> HTML tags.
For bigger chunks of code, use the <screen> tag. Just wrap your code block in it, mono-spacing with indents, and DocBook takes care of it automatically.

important.simpara: Brackets inside the <screen> tag must be represented in code: opening bracket is represented as < and the closing bracket is represented as >.

chapter.title: Links and Cross-references
chapter.para: Linking falls into two different categories: inside the version's set of books (for example, everything underneath &docpath;) and any links outside of the set.

section.title: Cross-referencing within a version's docs (<link> and <xref>)
section.para: By having unique id's, you can cross-reference any section within a version's doc with a simple tag, regardless of where that section is.

note.simpara: The 4.0 docs were set up differently; in those docs, you can only use this method of internal linking within the same book (project).

section.title: Using <xref>
section.para: The following is an example of a cross-reference (using the <xref> tag):
And the HTML/PDF output looks like the following:
Find information about headings in .
Note that this is an empty tag, you must either:

listitem.para: Provide the end-tag, </xref>, or
Put a slash before the ending-bracket: <xref linkend="blahblah"/>
If you want the section's title in the link, make sure you add the .

section.para: The <xref> tag is really only useful if there is an in the target element. If in doubt, or if you want to use your own wording as the link text, you'll need to use the <link> tag (as described below).

section.title: Linking internally with <link>
section.para: The following is an example of a link (using the <link> tag):
section.screen: <para>Find information about headings by clicking <link linkend="heading">here</link>.</para>
section.para: And the HTML/PDF output looks like the following:
Find information about headings by clicking here.

section.title: Linking outside a version's docs with <ulink>
section.para: If you are linking outside of your version's documentation, use the <ulink> tag:
The output will create a hyper-link to Oracle in the HTML-version of the documentation: Oracle Corporation.

important.simpara: Do NOT use ampersands in your hyper links. These are reserved for referencing entities; instead, use the following code for ampersand: & .

chapter.title: Graphics (<figure>)

note.simpara: Currently this section only takes HTML output into consideration - not a PDF version.

chapter.para:
To insert a graphic we use the <figure>, <mediaobject>, and <imageobject> elements.
You should also provide a brief description wrapped in <textobject> - in HTML this will be the ALT text. If you want a caption to appear below the graphic, use the <caption> element with a <para> tag.

note.para: The path to the graphic should start from the root of the documentation set. The one exception is if you are using a graphic outside of your 'family' (data/, info/, etc), you need to start from your directory, go back up 2 levels (../../) and then use the path to the graphic from there.

chapter.para: The HTML output looks like this:

textobject.phrase: This is an image of the flow in WebMDS

caption.para: This is an image of the flow in WebMDS

chapter.para: In addition to using the above code, do the following:

listitem.para: In general, put your graphics in the same directory as the document.
Keep the width of the graphic no greater than 700px (500px is best).

chapter.title: Lists
chapter.para: In general, making a list in DocBook is similar to doing the same thing in HTML - except in DocBook, <li> becomes <listitem> and the text in each <listitem> must be wrapped in in either a <para> or <simpara> element.
The following sections describe how to make the DocBook equivalent of the three usual HTML lists: unordered lists, ordered lists and definition lists.

section.title: How to make an unordered list (<itemizedlist>)
section.para: The HTML/PDF output looks like this:

listitem.para: Stuff goes here
More stuff goes here

section.title: How to make an ordered list (<orderedlist>)
section.para: The HTML/PDF output looks like this:

listitem.para: Stuff goes here
More stuff goes here

section.title: How to make a definition list (<variablelist>)
section.para: This kind of list is called a "variable list" in DocBook and is a little more complex than the previous lists. These are the tags you'll need to make it happen: <variablelist>, <varlistentry>, <term> and <listitem>:
section.screen: <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>Definition term goes here</term> <listitem><para>And definition/description goes here</para></listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>Another term goes here</term> <listitem><para>And more stuff goes here</para></listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist>
section.para: The HTML/PDF output looks like this:

listitem.para: And definition/description goes here
And more stuff goes here

section.para: Remember, each <listitem> must be wrapped in in either a <para> or <simpara> element.

chapter.title: Tables (<informaltable>)
chapter.para: DocBook supports several types of tables, but in most cases, the <informaltable> is enough:
The output is a simple HTML table:

row.entry: header1
header2
header3
a1
b1
c1
a2
b2
c2
a3
b3
c3

chapter.para: If you want cells to span more than one row or column, it gets a bit more complicated - check out <table> for more information.

chapter.title: Italics and Bold (<emphasis>)
chapter.para: Our documentation uses two flavors of emphasis - italics and bold type. DocBook uses one - <emphasis>.
The <emphasis> tag defaults to italics when parsed. If you want to emphasize with bold type, use <emphasis role="strong">.

para.emphasis: This little sentence uses just the <emphasis> tag.
This little sentence uses the <emphasis role="strong"> tag.

chapter.title: Calling attention to text
chapter.para: DocBook provides a few elements that can be very useful for calling attention to certain information by setting them off from the text: <caution>, <important>, <tip>, and <warning>.

section.title: <caution>
section.para: The following are examples of each type (using the DocBook examples):
section.screen: <caution><title>No User Servicable Parts Inside</title> <para> Breaking this seal voids all warranties. </para> </caution>

caution.title: No User Servicable Parts Inside
caution.para: Breaking this seal voids all warranties.

section.title: <important>
section.screen: <important> <para> No user-servicable parts inside. Breaking this seal voids all warranties. </para> </important>

important.para: No user-servicable parts inside. Breaking this seal voids all warranties.

section.title: <note>
section.screen: <note><title>Upcoming Changes</title> <para> Future versions of this feature may not be backward-compatible. Consider implementing the revised interface now. </para> </note>

note.title: Upcoming Changes
note.para: Future versions of this feature may not be backward-compatible. Consider implementing the revised interface now.

section.title: <tip>
section.screen: <tip> <para> If you tie your shoelaces, you're less likely to trip and fall down. </para> </tip>

tip.para: If you tie your shoelaces, you're less likely to trip and fall down.

section.title: <warning>
section.screen: <warning> <para> Striking your thumb with a hammer may cause severe pain and discomfort. </para> </warning>

warning.para: Striking your thumb with a hammer may cause severe pain and discomfort.

chapter.title: Glossary
chapter.para: The glossary for each version's release manuals is found online at [path to doc version]/glossary.html For example, we'll use the (current) development docs directory: &docpath;glossary.html.
Every project should make sure that any jargon or special terms appear in this list. To do so you need to add some markup in two places:

listitem.simpara: [path to doc version]/glossary.xml - This file acts as the centralized glossary database. Terms are added in <glossdiv> tags that correspond to the appropriate letter of the alphabet. For example, if you wanted to add the term "proxy certificate", you would open glossary.xml, look for the <glossdiv>P</glossdiv> section and add the following markup in alpha order with the other terms:
listitem.screen: <glossentry id="proxy-cert"><glossterm>proxy certificate</glossterm> <glossdef> <para> A short lived certificate issued using a EEC. A proxy certificate typically has the same effective subject as the EEC that issued it and can thus be used in its place. GSI uses proxy certificates for single sign on and delegation of rights to other entities.</para> </glossdef> </glossentry>

where the text after the pound sign (#) is equal to the id attribute in the <glossentry> tag in glossary.xml.

note.para: Note that &docpath; is a system entity that maps to the url of the path to the docs.

chapter.title: Indexing

note.para: This is a very new feature in documentation and will probably not be fully implemented until final release of 4.2. The Documentation Coordinator will be sending emails to gtmanuals-dev@globus.org on this subject.

chapter.para: You should mark up words in your documents that you would like to see show up in an index (which appears at the end of a project's table of contents). We are working on using specialized indexes to consolidate certain information (such as "how tos").
Use <indexterm>, <primary> and <secondary> for this. See these links for an explanation.
